Robust - Structured Error Handling
15/21

Exception handling allows for more robust programs.

  • Exception: signal thrown for an exceptional condition (e.g. file not found)
  • Part of class method declarations
  • Users are forced to catch Exceptions thrown by a method
  • Extensible (you can define your own Exceptions)
  • Allows structured error handling and recovery
What is Java ?

|X| Notes

When a security violation occurs the JVM can throw an exception or an error, which may result in de death of the offending thread but shouldn't crash the system.

Throwing an error almost always results in the death of the thread in which the error was thrown, but won't necessarily result in termination of the entire program.

Throwing an exception may result in the death of the thread, but is often used as a way to transfer control from the point in the program where the exception condition arose to the point where the exception is handled. The Java compiler forces programmers to deal with exceptions that methods declare they may throw. 

int number;
String value = "123abc";
try
{
	number = Integer.valueOf(value).intValue();
}
catch (NumberFormatException e)
{
	System.err.println("You entered an invalid number!");
	System.err.println("I will use '0'.");
	number = 0;
}
